instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.P5VS5_EN: What is P5VS5_EN? P5VS5_EN is a signal that turns on the PP5V_S5 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.P1V8S3_EN: What is P1V8S3_EN? P1V8S3_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V8_S3 line when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Board isn't powering up. Found corrosion on and around <CHIP>U8190</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1830</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8192</CHIP>, and Q440. Along with the corrosion, UB400 was cycling on and off. Once the corrosion was cleaned, the cycle was fixed and we now have 20v on all 4 usb-c ports. Also, replaced <RESISTOR>R1452</RESISTOR> due to it being corroded. But the board is still not power up. 

Measuring and found


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS5_EN</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4

Anything else to check or any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage (without battery)?
Is the battery charging?

Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10) voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.06
Going to put the board back in to see if it charges

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> pins 7 and 10 are ground pins.
[ATTACH type="full" alt="1654956940084.png"]60658[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_PMICLDO</SIGNAL> - 0.01
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_PMICVREF</SIGNAL> - 0"
Check diode mode to ground.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> is present?
If not, check <RESISTOR>R7865</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Now post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>: pins 23, 22, 12, 13, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Found the issue while checking <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>. <CAPACITOR>C7651</CAPACITOR> was broken off pad 1 side. Once fixed, board now comes to life. Thanks again for the assist.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Now that i have the board working, no usb activity other than a flash upon initial plug in. I do have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> at 5.1v. Any suggestions on what else to check on this board? Could it be related to the corrosion i had cleaned up on and around <CHIP>U8190</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1830</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8192</CHIP>, and Q440?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at L3500 and LB700?
Test connecting an USB device on corresponding ports.

Mentioned components don't seem to have USB relation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Yes, 5v on L3500 ans LB700 with usb drive connected to each ports

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: Did you test all ports, in both modes USB 2/3?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
What for these measurmentes?
You didn't mention any video issue.

USB 2 and USB 3 failure in same way?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Sorry, I should Iâ€™ve also included that theowner had just messaged me that the original issue he had was no image on display. When I got it, it was completely dead until after the repair of the corrosion damage.
Regarding usb2 and 3 testing, other than finding a usb 2.0 and 3.0 device to test, is there another way to test this?
Also The cpu is warm, normal running temp.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
You should compare <SIGNAL>EDP_INT</SIGNAL> readings with similar board, maybe 00923.
00281 has discrete graphics and <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> analog MUX placed on these lines.

"Now that i have the board working"
Working what, if no USB activity, nor video???
Turned on board is not same like working!

Check L7210 voltage after 10-15 seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message: L7210 - 1.12 after 15sec. Stays at this and doesn't change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up
threads.message:
Then the board doesn't boot; no reason to expect USB activity, nor video.

Try known good BIOS, just in case.
